div.l: Than were ther yong poor͗e scolers two
Þat duelt in the halle of which I seye
Testif thei were and lusti forto pley
And only for their͗e myrth ⁊and reuelry
Vpon̄ the wardeyn̄ bisily they crye
To yeve them̄ leve but a litle stound
To go to Mille to se their corn̄ y ground
And hardili thei durst ley their necke
Þe Milner shuld not stele half a pecke
Of corne / bi sleight ne bi force hem reve
And at last the wardein yave hem leue
John hight that one and Aleyn̄ hight þᵗat oþ̉er
Of one tovne were þei born̄ þᵗat hiȝt Strot̉er
Ferre in the north I can̄ not telle where
This Aleyn̄ makith alle redi his gere
And on an hors the sacke he cast anon̄
Furth goth aleyn̄ the clerk and eke John
With good swerd and bokeler bi their͗e side
Iohn knew the wey him neded no guyde
And at Mille the sacke adoun̄ he leith
Aleyn spak first al hail Simond in faith
Hou faris thi fare doughtir and thi wif
Aleyn welcum qᵈuod Simkyn̄ be my lif
And Iohn also hou now what done ye her͗e
A Sentence Be god qᵈuod Iohn nede has no pere

l.hi: Him bud ʆserue him selue that has no swayn̄

div.l: Or ellis he is a fole as clerkis seyn̄
Oure maunciple I hope wille be dede
So wirkꝭis ay the wangis in his hede
And therefore I is comen̄ and eke aleyn̄
To grynd oure corn̄ and cary it home ageyn
I pray you spede us henne as hastili as ye may
It shal be done qᵈuod Symkin be my fay
What wil ye do whils it is in hand
Be god right bi the hopir wille I stand
Qduod Iohn and se hou the hopir gos ynne
Yit saw I neuer be my fadir kynn
